## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/sparsesetvaltraits">SparseSetValTraits</a> - Objects in a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sparseset">SparseSet</a> are identified by keys that can be uniquely converted to a small integer less than the set&#39;s universe.

This class allows the set to hold values that differ from the set&#39;s key type as long as an index can still be derived from the value. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sparseset">SparseSet</a> never directly compares ValueT, only their indices, so it can map keys to arbitrary values. <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/sparsesetvaltraits">SparseSetValTraits</a> computes the index from the value object. To compute the index from a key, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sparseset">SparseSet</a> uses a separate KeyFunctorT template argument.

A simple type declaration, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sparseset">SparseSet&lt;Type&gt;</a>, handles these cases:
<ul>
<li>unsigned key, identity index, identity value</li>
<li>unsigned key, identity index, fat value providing getSparseSetIndex()</li>
</ul>


The type declaration <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sparseset">SparseSet&lt;Type, UnaryFunction&gt;</a> handles:
<ul>
<li>unsigned key, remapped index, identity value (virtual registers)</li>
<li>pointer key, pointer-derived index, identity value (node+ID)</li>
<li>pointer key, pointer-derived index, fat value with getSparseSetIndex()</li>
</ul>


Only other, unexpected cases require specializing <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/sparsesetvaltraits">SparseSetValTraits</a>.

For best results, ValueT should not require a destructor.

Definition at line 57 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/sparseset-h">SparseSet.h</a>.
